author: Flynoceros

description.text:
link to video
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WZav_TWVLng

I saw a video on youtube where a milling machine levelled it's own bed by cutting a tiny layer off the surface and thought this concept may be a good way to level your bed for cold bed printing. It's opposite of the milling concept but it should work. 
The idea being that as you print the shim the height differences would be levelled out by the act of the plastic not being squashed down on the low parts. As more layers are printed the process finds the level by gravity for the low areas and compression for the high areas.
I think 3 to 5mm high would be enough to level out the low spots, this is just an idea whilst I rebuild my printer. 
A simple structure like the attached stl sized for your bed should not use up much plastic. You may need to run some sandpaper over it to clean up bulge for the high spots.

Size for your print bed and print onto your lowest level surface, leave it on the surface and cover with glass or whatever, should leave you with a perfectly levelled bed.
The stl is sized 19cm X 19cm X 3mm, obj model included.
Update, it works well but TBH if you can print this then your bed is kinda level anyway!

comments.text: I didn't use this to level my bed, but it did serve as an excellent quick-print indicator of what points were high or low.

description.text:

Will not interfere with stock Taz5 setup (with stock unmodified carriage), though have not tested with other addons - a revised version of this revised version may be uploaded with a shorter duct section which would increase clearance.

remixed_from.author: MacNite
remixed_from.title: E3D V6 Mount with Fan for CTC / Flashforge / Replicator

title: E3D V6 Mount with Fan for CTC / Flashforge / Replicator - Reversible

description.text:
I loved the design by MacNite, but wanted to show off those beautiful E3D heatsinks! So I took his design and re-mixed it so that the fans would mount on the back and the E3D heatsinks would be shown in all their glory...

Note that even with my changes, the mount can still be mounted the way that MacNite designed it - it's really your choice. ;-)

I also made the following improvements:

  • Modified the mount so that both hotends are adjustable about 2mm in total, making leveling quite a bit easier.
  • Increased the wire 'tunnel' size a bit to make wire routing a little easier.
  • Added a fin to force about 60% of the air to the lower portion of the heatsink for better cooling (where it needs it the most)
  • Shrunk the mounting holes for the fans a little bit so that M3 screws will thread right into the plastic with no need for long screws and nuts for the fans.

Note: I re-used the CTC Heater Blocks, Heaters and Thermocouples from the original CTC hotends, but used everything else from the E3D [clone] Hotends (IE: E3D Heatsinks, E3D All Metal Heat Brakes and E3D Nozzles)

7/19/2016 - I added a couple of re-mixes of the Bowden Coupling mount for PC4-M6 couplings. There are two designs - one simply has a 2mm path for the filament, the other has a 4mm path in order to mount a piece of 4mm OD PTFE tubing in the end to extend all the way to the extruder's gear & bearing. (Make sure to use a drill bit to clean up the inner surface!. ;-) ) Note that these are UNTESTED - so if you print and use them, let me know if they work out well so that I can update this text.

Printer:

CTC Dual

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.25

Infill:

60%

Notes:

Supports are only needed for the mount point - so if you're using S3D, just add them in manually there (where there is a 90 degree overhang). Everywhere else should be fine without support.

comments.text: Great Remix, using it for 6 months now, working perfectly!

comments.author: Ivan_l

comments.text:
These are relatively cheap chinese clones from either eBay or Alidata, I forget which. IMHO, the main thing that sets a genuine hotend apart from the cheap clones is the quality of the heat brake and nozzle. The cheap clones I bought had a 14mm deep section at the top of the heat brake for the PTFE tube to go in to, way too deep, so the PTFE tubing was basically in the hot zone of the hotend and they would clog constantly. The genuine hotend has only a 4mm deep section for the PTFE tubing to seat into.
This problem is easily fixed though by purchasing a 'polished' heat brake. This makes a clone work just as good as a genuine hotend. (Oh, and I'd suggest the 'all metal' ones, not the ones with PTFE liners)
Here's a couple of sources that I've bought polished heat brakes from - both work perfectly:
http://www.ebay.com/itm/331888311290 (China seller - cheaper, but much slower to ship to USA)
http://www.ebay.com/itm/121977814369 (USA seller - Shipping is much faster, but they cost a lot more!)

Hi caall99 - I'm not aware of those value names, but I also don't use the 'stock' software to control my printer - I use Simplify3D. But I'm guessing you're asking for my retraction values.
And as I mentioned in the description, I'm using E3D V6 'clones'. The values for Genuine E3D hotends may be slightly different, but these should at least get you in 'the ballpark'...
comments.author: caall99

comments.text: JKN Advance K and K2 are nozzle pressure compensation values for acceleration and deceleration. It is a Sailfish firmware feature that you can edit by connecting ReplicatorG to your printer. I have K at 3 and K2 at the stock 0.055. This seems to work for me. With K at the stock 0.005, I was extruding FAR TOO MUCH plastic during acceleration and deceleration.

comments.text:
Hi m1n1m,
So the CTC heat brake will not fit in an E3D V6, as it's smooth on the 'top/cool' side. But the stock heater block has 6mm threads, so the E3D style heat brake will thread right into it. That's what I did initially, until I got over-zealous and stripped out the 'stock' heater block. Then I switched to the E3D V6 style heater blocks, and everything worked great. ;-)
The text description tells how to do it. You'd need:
E3D V6 hotends (or clones)
PTFE tubing - as the extruders are converted to Bowden
Two PTFE fittings (PC4-01 recommended) for the Bowden conversion.
Misc 3MM screws and nuts as documented. (at least I -think- it's documented in the thing - let me know if it's not, and I'll take measurements of mine for you and update the instructions...)
That's about it - everything else is 'recycled' from the stock parts.

comments.author: MontagueFlange

comments.text: Cool. I get you there about the thermocouple. I have no MK10 heater blocks left, finding them hard to find for a fair price here at the moment. So was looking at a full on upgrade. The other thing I was looking at was using the Titan extruder and making it direct drive. The printer is up against the wall so no room on the back for filaments and motors.
comments.author: jartz

comments.text:
Why not mount the spools and extruders up top? Then you could keep the dual extruders if you wanted to...
I was looking to see if there was room inside the printer (on either side of the bed, like the Dremel printer), but it's about 10-20mm short... d'oh!
How about on the left and right sides of the printer, or both on one side? Lots of possibilities...
comments.author: MontagueFlange

comments.text:
PS: I stripped out one of the 'stock' heater blocks by accident, so I switched both of them to the E3D heater blocks a few days ago. It seems to print a little bit better, which seems strange to me as the 'stock' ones have a bit more mass to them... ;-) Maybe it's just the 'placebo effect'?
I had mounted them with the heaters towards the BACK of the printer.
And I somehow popped my 'Extruder 2' driver chip, so I'm going to adjust (hack) a standard A4988 driver to plug into the Mightyboard. The 'stock' CTC drivers actually use the A4988 chip already (even though the Mightyboard design specifies the 4928), and a 'standard' 4988 Polulo driver won't fit as the pinout is 'flipped' and has a special pin for electronic control of the voltage reference. I'm going to 'hack' a standard A4988 board to fit. ;-) It's not all that hard with the right tools, and I happen to have 'the right tools', LOL!
comments.author: jartz

comments.text: wich e3d v6 should i take? long or short?

comments.text: I have a couple of 'normal' E3D V6 'clone' hotends in here.  I'm not sure what you mean by 'long or short' - the only parts of the E3D hotend that I didn't use was the Heater Block, Heater Cartridge, and Thermistors.  Everything else is from the E3D hotend (Nozzle, Heat Brake, Heatsink, PTFE tube clamp)

title: Folger Technologies i3 2020 Full Lead Screw Upgrade on all axis

description.text:
Folger Technologies i3 2020 Full Lead Screw Upgrade on all axis.

1st Thanks to GarRemMash (http://www.thingiverse.com/GarRemMash/about) for the original Z & X kit. This kit got me thinking of that all that was needed was to add the Y Axis to make full lead screw machine. The result is a full 190 x 190 x 180 mm print area.

This upgrade is not for the novice. The upgrade just about takes the whole kit apart, re-squares and re-assembles; please plan ahead accordingly. Check your parts, parts lists, and be sure you have everything (else you'll be borrowing a friends printer for parts)
** Do this upgrade at your own risk, for additional support join the Folger Technologies Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/groups/Folgertech3dPrinters/

Videos in action:
https://www.facebook.com/James.M.Beam/videos/10207023617811768/
https://www.facebook.com/James.M.Beam/videos/10207034929934564/

Important note: The lead screw drive limits build speed to a nominal 50 mm/s travels / on some parts you can go to 60 mm/s. I have tried going above with very mixed results. For example, I have had some parts do great at 75 mm/s where others will skip and fail. If you have ANY reservations about this upgrade I definitely do not recommend it.

Printer:

Folger Tech i3 2020 Alum

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

100% for rigidity

Notes:

I used ABS for most parts; however, PLA will work just fine.

General Notes

Be sure to trim & edge parts, as well as test fit before major disassembly.

I found keeping the steppers at the top, with the extensions, with the 608ZZ bearings, then on the lower plate side adding a thrust bearing, then a collar to clamp the screw the best way to stop the flex coupling from stretching (in fact with this setup, it cannot). It's more expensive (and time consuming to setup); but, I get great 0.2 mm layers every time. This also solves a lot of the bed leveling issues too as Z is locked (does not change with up / down movements).
Assembly for the Z-Axis setup needs thrust bearings installed in this order::

  • Stepper motor
  • Extension mount
  • Flex coupling
  • 608ZZ bearing
  • mount plate
  • thrust bearing
  • collar to clamp
    When installed correctly, the flex coupling will not expand or contract with Z axis movements adding more accuracy to your prints.

Here are few photos of prints made with this setup:

https://www.instagram.com/p/BMPxU5_hMjh/
https://www.instagram.com/p/BMHpq-6hyvj/
https://www.instagram.com/p/BLziwdxhaWt/
https://www.instagram.com/p/BLpxrsVhaCo/
https://www.instagram.com/p/BM33Nh_BFI1/
https://www.instagram.com/p/BLXHkCdBe9f/
https://www.instagram.com/p/BJVjv2-BPqR/
https://www.instagram.com/p/BJUYjxiBbJb/
https://www.instagram.com/p/BIxpfAuBc5m/

Benefits I see are:

1) increased accuracy & precision
the lead screws have no play & move more with each rotation than a GT2 belt
Igus bearings add to the above
able to get +/- 0.05 (or less) dimensions on a 20 mm test cube

2) less ringing in the layers, lead screws are quieter/less vibration than a GT2 belt

3) allows for heavier "ends"
so one of my plans was to add a laser cutter option or even a mini-mill via a Dremel with a flex shaft to the cutting tool

4) bonus feature is increase build Z height (can get this with a belted upgrade as well) - mine happens to maximize this to 180 mm (technically, I can go 184 mm, but that is really close to crash at the top)

5) not fully tested, but speeds are as fast as a belt; maybe faster. This requires more tweaking of firmware settings and stepper motor voltages - could spend weeks driving to ultimate levels. Not my intent as #1 was the prime objective, accurate parts.

6) Well someone had to do it . . .

Parts!

1st you'll need the parts in this post

Additionally you'll need:
Lead Screws
2x 300 mm
https://folgertech.com/products/300mm-lead-screw-3d-printer-z-axis-lead-screw-300mm-lead-screw-8mm-screw-pitch
2x 400 mm
https://folgertech.com/products/400mm-lead-screw-3d-printer-z-axis-lead-screw-acme-lead-screw-8mm-screw-pitch
1X 8mm Brass Lead Scew Nut 1x (needed for anit-back lash Y axis
https://folgertech.com/collections/lead-screws/products/8mm-brass-lead-screw-nut

Bearings for Y Axis
https://folgertech.com/products/2pcs-self-align-8mm-bore-inner-ball-mounted-pillow-block-insert-bearing-kp08

4x Stepper Motor Couplings
https://folgertech.com/products/5mm-to-8mm-flexible-coupling-od-19mm-x-25mm-for-cnc-and-prusa-3d-printers

Z Axis Motor Risers:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1288802

Corner braces:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1387216

My Fan bracket & Servo Arm for Z probe
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1481551

Blower Duct from
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:976189

Dual Bearing mount for Y table:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1120328

All stepper motors replaced with this one:
https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B0196FH94E

Thrust washers and collars
4x of these: https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B00DN5KYT6
1x (set of 4) of these: https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B0063KWIYC/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

12 Igus Bearings
https://folgertech.com/collections/bearings/products/igus-rj4jp-01-08-8mm-linear-bearing-to-replace-lm8uu

6x 8MM ID Skate Bearings:
https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B002BBGTK6

Optional: (anti-backlash nut & spring) will need 3x
http://www.ebay.com/itm/322089168774
If used, the part "Z_leadscrew_antibacklash_rev2" will need to be mirrored for 1x
One being left side, the other being right side.
Also, the Z nuts will require to be trimmed with a cut off wheel to fit.

I've not listed every 3mm / 4mm screw and T-nut. But plan for several.
** You'll need to review the assembly and make a check list for this.

Here are a few to review:
https://folgertech.com/products/12-x-lm8uu-4-x-608zz-2-x-623zz-bearing-kit-prusa-i3-rework-reprap-3d-printer
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B014ONCP88/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B010CRN2SC/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B003KWER3Q/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1
https://folgertech.com/products/four-4-internal-cast-2020-corner-bracket-fittings-industrial-aluminum
https://folgertech.com/products/four-4-2020-corner-bracket-fittings-industrial-aluminum

Photos should should show the remaining notes.
Note the Power supply and ramps are moved to the outside 2020 frame so the lower brace arm can install.

Note: I remixed the Y-Axis thread holder from here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:718386

2017-01-01 UPDATE
FARGKENOB created a great Y Axis Stepper Motor mount here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2007186

I have updated to this part & suggest any builders do the same.
Simply cut the extra spool holder 2020 pc in half (~70.6 mm) and mount per the pictures shown shown here: http://www.thingiverse.com/make:283086

TNSI created a better Z-Axis Leadscrew Guide also here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1937927

I have also updated to this part and recommend this part be used instead of the "z_axis_guide_bearing_leadscrew" as it can be installed/removed/replaced without removing the guide rod.

Some more details on how the bearings go together:
Z axis (top to bottom) is stepper motor->shaft couple->skate bearing (shaft couple rests on the skate bearing), bracket, thrust bearing, collar.

X Axis (right to left) is stepper motor->shaft couple->thrust bearing (shaft couple rests on the thrust bearing)->skate bearing->right mount->skate bearing->collar ->carriage<- skate bearing, mount, skate bearing, thrust bearing, collar.

Added some more photos to help clarify.

Trick is to tension all the load onto the skate bearings & thrust bearings such that the shaft couples do not expand/stretch as the lead screws move. The expand/stretching of the couples cause offsets, wobbles, in prints.

BOM Cost for the Essentials

$ 18.00 -- PLA or ABS spool for printed parts - plan to use about 50%

$ 20.00 -- 300 mm lead screws (2x @ $10 ea) - both for Z axis

$ 32.00 -- 400 mm lead screws (2x @ $16 ea) - one for X axis one for Y axis

$ 7.00 -- 8mm Brass Lead Scew Nut 1x (needed for anit-back lash Y axis

$ 8.00 -- Pillow bearings (set of 2) for Y axis

$ 8.00 -- 5mm To 8mm Flexible Coupling (4x @ $2 ea)

$ 60.00 -- High Torque NEMA 17 Stepper Motors (4x @ $15 ea)

$ 27.00 -- Thrust bearings (4x @ $6.75 ea)

$ 20.00 -- MSC-8-SS Set Screw Shaft Collar (pack of 4)

$ 24.00 -- Igus Bearings (12x @ $2 ea) - optional but worth the cost

$ 10.00 -- VXB 608 ZZ Skate bearing (pack of 8) will be two left over

$ 27.00 -- 8mm T8x8 Lead Screw Anti-Backlash Nut kit (3x @ $9 ea)

$ 15.00 -- Hitec HS-55 Servo

-------------

$ 275.00 -- total

** My cost justification:

Larger kits exist for the cost of this upgrade and the original 2020 kit; but, they don't fit in my space for my printer.

Larger kits still use belts - I wanted the added accuracy w/o loss of speed by using lead screws - and ever tightening a belt again.

Settings & Firmware 101

Firmware Setup 101

Stepper motor voltage settings:
X set to 0.7 V
Y set to 0.9 V
Z set to 1.4 V ( 2x 0.7 V)

Note: I'm using DRV8825 stepper drivers.

Firmware adjustments:
I wasn't able to find these in any calculators or other methods with Google. I started with the belt speeds and ran into big problems fast (skipping and jerking), So with some research I found the rates are about 1/10 th that of belt speeds. Appears that the lead screws accelerate much faster than the belts so the feed rate and accelerations all had to change.

So I ended up with these numbers:
HOMING_FEEDRATE {3000, 3000, 125, 0} // from 50 to: 125 speeds up the Z rate for faster homing
DEFAULT_MAX_FEEDRATE = {50, 50, 50 , 22}
DEFAULT_MAX_ACCELERATION = {100,100,100,1000}
DEFAULT_ACCELERATION = 50
DEFAULT_RETRACT_ACCELERATION = 50
DEFAULT_TRAVEL_ACCELERATION = 50
DEFAULT_XYJERK = 20.0
DEFAULT_ZJERK = 20.0
These rates give very smooth movements.

Repetier:
I changed the following:
Travel Feed Rate to: 3600 max (works better at 2400)
Z Axis Feed Rate to: 3600 max (works better at 2400)
Manual Retraction Speed to: 20

Only number I would change from here is the feed rate, but even then they should not go over {60, 60, 60, 22}.

Lead screws with Igus bearings have a higher drag; but, are dead accurate at a stop (no slack or back lash). So the penalty for accuracy is slightly reduced speed.

Other Tricks & Stuff to support:

X Axis level brackets:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:280974

Display Holder & bracket
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:684778
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1162767

Filament guide:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1133632

2020 End caps
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1341399

Front cooling fan cover:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1101002 or
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1107366

Ramps Cooling Fan
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:30331

Allen Wrench holder:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1375996

PEI sheet:
https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B01DTLWU6I
or
https://smile.amazon.com/Polyetherimide-Natural-Standard-Tolerance-Thickness/dp/B0013HKZTA

Kork for Bed insulation (will have to groove and cut to fit)
https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B000HJB9OK

Ceramic insulation tape for the hot end (optional)
https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B00KSLT6FG

This Parametric Angle was inititally designed to reinforce a Prusa Mendel frame. However, it can be used and adapted for many other applications. It is fully parametric so you can change length, angle, thickness etc. 
configuration.scad, metric.scad, functions.scad and teardrop.scad are taken and adapted from the Prusa Mendel. They are licenced under GPL.

You need 4-8 m3 bolts and 4-8 m3 nuts for the precompiled versions. 3 different precompiled versions are supplied. "Cylinder" and "Teardrop" are both cylindrical, but teardrop is easier to print. The "Cube" version is for rods with rectangular shape. The source file is written in OpenScad
http://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/OpenSCAD_User_Manual http://www.openscad.org/ If you want to create a different version, you will need to download all files ending with .scad and save them in the same directory, ensuring they are named properly. Then, simply open angle.scad and edit the parameters in the section "Local Settings". Hit Design->"Compile and Render" and Design->"Export as STL" and you're done.

title: Dual Fan Duct for Rostock Printer

description.text:
These are two individual fan ducts for 40x40mm fans for the Rostock printer (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:17175), one for the thermal barrier and one for cooling the print.

Needed for assembly:
40x40mm fans (2x)
M3x16mm Screws (11x)
M3 Nuts (9x)
M3 Washers (3x)

The reason I designed this is:
I used to print with a single fan attached to the delta printer plattform which was always on and blew a constant stream of air over the print bed. Unfortunately the airstream also lifted up the corners and some printed lines of my first layer, so I tried to turn the fan off for the first layers. This led to jamming of the filament in the thermal barrier, so I needed constant cooling for the thermal barrier but a tweakable cooling regime for the printed parts.

Assembly:
The three washers go to the three screws that attach the fan ducts to the platform.

FanDuctPart1 needs two be assembled first to the platform and then the fan can be mounted.

The second fan should be mounted to FanDuctPart2 before assembly to the platform. The two holes near the print center do not have enough space for a nut.

Check if your printed bed is still level after assembly, I needed to recalibrate my printer a little bit.

Printer:

Rostock

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

100

Notes:

I printed FanDuctPart1 without support and without brim.
FanDuctPart2 is quite difficult to print, I printed it with support material and a brim. Still there are some regions where the part tends to warp, especially at the thin walls.
Carefully remove the support material of FanDuctPart2.

title: APR - 1 The Air Powered Rocket
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Hi my name is Zander, and I bring you the APR -1 the first ever Compact Grid Fin Air Powered Sabot Rocket. This cool looking rocket combines missile stabilization, Tank Sabot, and air powered rockets together to be launched from a potato gun.

P.S I used 1" PVC cut to 6" for the body. You can print the body tube out if you wish, Or buy or use some 1" PVC.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa I3

Resolution:

0.25/0.1

Infill:

100%

Notes:

You may need to use Rafts on the grid fins.

Clean Up

After the parts are printed you will need to remove support material, and rafts if you chose to do so.

Sanding/Glueing

With my printer I had to sand the Rear Taper connector for a while to get it to fit, and I used superglue to secure it.

Design

For this design I knew I would need to have stabilization. When you launch a potato out of a cannon it is round and will act more like a cannon ball. But when you make a Tube or Stick you will have to design it like a rocket. So I had to make some kind of stabilization. I went toward the Grid fin design because it can be used to control the vessel with the right engineering, and they look cool!
When designing a rocket you want the center of mass to be towards the nose and the center of pressure in the back close to the engine or rear of the vessel. Look at the picture at you may understand this better.

Thank you for viewing my "Thing" and have a good one!

~Zander

title: Tiki Torch Ground Spike Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The ground under my lawn is pretty hard so I always need to use a bucket with dirt to hold my tiki torches. I designed this to be inserted into the ground with your foot or hammer and then insert the stick of the tiki torch into the holder. You can leave the spike in all year round and mow your lawn as long as it is in the ground all the way. Quality doesn't matter on this so it took about 1.5 hr to print @ 180mm/s. ABS is recommended but I think PLA will work just as well because it's designed to be tough.

The hole is 28mm in diameter. Please use your math skills to adjust the x & y ratio to fit your tiki torch sticks as they are all different sizes. Allow 2mm wiggle room at least. I'll even make it easy for you. [stick diameter (mm) + 2mm] divide by [28mm] = x & y scale ratio to enter into your printing program.

CAUTION
This print was slightly taller than my printer could handle. Please measure your printer to make sure it can print 150mm high, if not, reduce. If you're not sure, be present when it reaches the end if you don't have an upper z-stop like I do. I am not responsible for any damage caused by operator negligence.

ENJOY your outdoor events!

description.text:
Unless you have a really good reason for using this particular version of this model, please consider using Prot0typ1cal's remix, which improves upon this version in pretty much every way imaginable. Get it at:

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1662717

After installing a Flexion extruder on a Replicator 2, the fan duct mount no longer fits. The top of the extruder bumps against the plastic roof, and the right side of the roof covers the Flexion's dial. This fan duct mount fits on top of the Flexion, and leaves the top of the extruder accessible.

There are holes through the top of the duct mount that allow you to easily access the small hex screws on the inside of the duct mount (see second photo).

Attach cables with cable binder.

(The first photo shows the 40mm Fan Duct - Replicator 2X installed as well, in case you're wondering what's going on with the fan. Get it at at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:107080.)

remixed_from.author: DjDemonD
remixed_from.title: Smartrapcore Alu - Strengthened and anti resonance Upgraded Parts

title: Smartrapcore Alu - Rear L & R pulley holders/y rod supports fully supported

description.text:
These are the rear pulley holders for a smartrapcore alu printer. On the suggestion of some contributors to Reprap forum, I have remixed these originally from the parts by Smartfriendz but incorporating my strengthening modifications to prevent splitting of the original parts under belt tension. Now a fully supported pulley, this prevents twisting under belt tension by adding to the rigidity to the pulleys. It should prolong the life of this part also, which is under constant belt tension and the increased force when the belt moves.

The version of this printer I am using now has f608zz bearings instead of printed pulley sleeves, but they should still fit. You can use your original m8 bolt.

I've added two parts labelled experimental, if anyone cares to print them and try them and let me know how they get on I'd be grateful. The only change is I've added lugs to slot into the 2020 frame on the sides also, which should be fairly tight fitting, so file them a bit if needed, the idea being it might also help prevent twisting of the part under belt tension.

Please note a fellow reprap forum contributor has come up with an improved version of this type of design http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1678368 which offsets the pulleys. This seems very promising.

Notes:

Just print them strong ABS or PET/G works fine.

comments.text: Glad it helped. Good to know that works, been meaning to try it and never got chance.

I printed the 'updated' L holder, and the upgraded part fits perfectly.

title: Mk8 extruder rear heatsink + fan support

description.text:
This is a part designed for mk8 extruder.
It makes possible coupling a 40 x 40 mm GPU heatsink + fan over the stepper motor's rear face.
Before installing, some CPU thermal paste can be applied between the contact surfaces to increase the heat transfer and cooling features of the whole set.

Printer:

Prusa i3 Frame Box

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Recommended 0.2 mm / layer

Infill:

100% (small part)

Notes:

FreeCAD Design included.
Mine was an old ATI GPU 40 x 40 mm heatsink + fan set, but it could be fully customized for other sets easily as the design is included.
Thermal paste usage highly recommended.

comments.text: I am new to 3D printing, but I like this idea. I am pretty sure I have a few heat sinks that I could use or adapt for this. I have noticed the motor can get rather hot.
comments.author: Thumpr

comments.text:
Not only the cool side remains cool.
It maintains the whole motor block operating in an optimal temperature range even without thermal paste applied.
After almost a year using it in my Prusa i3 framebox, I have to say that it is a very smart cooling solution for MK8 extruder.

title: Replacment Cover for Stern Navigation Light
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The cover for the stern navigation marker light (white) on my classic runabout disintegrated after some 57 years of UV exposure. Not knowing the brand of the fixture and given its age, I didn't even bother looking for a replacement.

Initially I tried using syvwlch's SCAD thread library, but I was having stringing problems that required too much cleanup, so I hit on the idea of partial internal threads using a pattern of spheres.

I would have preferred to print this in nylon but didn't have enough on hand. The only other white material I had was PLA. In use it softens a bit due to the heat of the light bulb, but so far doesn't show signs of melting. YMMV!

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa Mendel i3

Notes:

This thing is 80mm high: I had to change my post-print settings to home Y instead of X upon completion to avoid crashing the extruder stepper into the frame of my Prusa Mendel i3 when it homes the X-axis.

Note

This thing is 80mm high: I have to remember to lower my extruder by at least 30mm before the next print to avoid crashing the extruder stepper into the frame of my Prusa Mendel i3 when it homes the X-axis.

description.text:
The idea for this project was to be used as a pump for cooling liquid on a lathe.

Using ideas from other similar designs, i created a new more efficient water pump.
All printed and tested in PLA with a printed rubber seal.

motor i designed this around was 28mm in diameter and the shaft was 2.2mm.

the water is output through a 5mm hose adapter (fish tank bubble tube).

I was able to tap the 4mm holes so i could screw straight into the plastic with M4 bolts

title: Customizable Universal Charging Dock
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
At the moment there is an error when you render this file: here is a temporary fix:
Download the file called "MobileHolderV6.scad" here from this thing. Download and install http://www.openscad.org/

Open MobileHolderV6.scad in OpenSCAD. There you can insert your values directly in the code and render your models locally on your own computer.

When you have inserted your values you click the "Render"-button. The one with the cube and an hour glass. After rendering you click the "STL"-button to get your STL-file. It is the first variable in the code that determine if you are working on the top holder or the connector. When you have rendered and saved the STL for the top holder change that variable to "second" and you will see the connector when you render.

It is easier than you think. And right now much more reliable than Thingiverse... :-/

I will keep trying to get in touch with support to resolve this issue. Until then use the solution described here

Having a charging dock for you phone is nice. But the problem is that you need a new one every time you change phone and it won't fit if you have added a cover or battery pack. That is not a problem any more.

This thing is a customizable phone dock for both Android, iPhone and almost all phones that have the connector at the bottom.

Simply print the base dock (UniversalDockBase.stl) and use the customizer to fit the top holder to your phone. Then customise the connector adapter to your cable or choose one of the included ones if you have a pretty standard cable.

When you get a new phone or add a cover to your existing one you can simply print a new top holder and/or a new connector adapter.

Update:
I have added an option to add extra support on the top holder to hold the phone better on board a car or boat. This is a feature that was first introduced in a separate thing:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1659903
...but is now included as an option in this thing.

Update2:
I have added two experimental options for the connector holder:

  1. An offset to let you finely adjust the connector a bit to the right or left
  2. An option to add an extra 10 mm of depth if you have a very thick cover or battery pack

Update3:
Thanks to user walkeraj (https://www.thingiverse.com/walkeraj/about) we now have an extra option to choose eliptical or square charging plug. And an extra Universal Dock Base with curved cable channel. Thank you!

Instructions:

Prepare
Look through all the images and the video (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=grWQgDPk3Ps). There are quite a bit of information there. Then prepare: All measures are in millimetre (mm). Measure the width of your phone. Including any cover that you use. Then measure the length from the back of the phone to the back of the connector. Please see the images at the top to learn what "the back of the connector" means. This is the "phone depth".

Then you have to decide what connector type you need. I have included adapters for Apple Lightning, Apple iPhone4/iPod and a standard Sony Micro USB.

If you don't use one of those connectors then use the included customizer to make an adapter that fits your plug. Measure the width, depth and height of your connector and enter the values in the customizer.

Print
I have printed mine on my LulzBot Mini using both PLA and ABS. You need to rotate the parts into place. The base is printed standing upright like it will when finished. No support needed. The top holder needs to be flipped in your software and printed upside down. No support needed. The connector adapter is printed standing upright at its 10 degrees angle. That way it can also print with no support.

Finish
The parts fits very tight. You probably need to do a little bit of sanding or cutting off excess edges in the bottom where you insert the connector adapter. Use bits of tape on the connector itself and the chord if it does not fit tight. You want the connector to sit tight so that it won't loose when you remove your phone.

I use double sided tape to fix the dock to my desk so that I can easily insert and remove the phone with one hand without having to hold the dock with the other hand.

Removing the top holder to exchange it can be hard. Use a thin screw driver and press it in between the base and the top holder at the back and twist slightly to loosen the top.

Measures for some common phones (Width - depth)
iPhone 3: 63 - 6
iPhone 4: 59 - 3
iPhone 5C: 60 - 4
iPhone 5C with Apple Cover: 63 - 6
iPhone 5S: 59 - 3
iPhone 5S with Mophie: 64 - 5
iPhone 6 plus with Apple cover: 82 - 5
iPhone 6 plus: 78 - 3
iPod 60GB: 62 - 7

Samsung Galaxy S7 Edge: 73 - 2
Samsung Galaxy S7 Edge with LED Cover: 76 - 5.6
Sony Xperia Z5 Pro: 77 - 3

Links to models and option to download of several file types:
Universal Dock Base: http://a360.co/29aB1HT
Clean Connector Adapter with no hole: http://a360.co/29dzTyE

The top holder is made entirely with OpenSCAD and you can download the source in the customizer.

comments.author: MrPeter

comments.text: You can probably trust the width on the spec page. Use that and add 1 mm to give a little room. The depth of the phone according to the spec you link to is 0.37" = 9.4 mm. Unfortunately it is not easy to know if this includes the camera lens. But if it is the total depth at the bottom of the phone: Usually the connector is more or less in the middle. So the length from the back of the phone to the back of the connector would be total depth of phone divided by two (9.4/2=4.7) minus depth of half the connector (approx 1 mm). Giving a "depth" for this mobile stand: 3.7 mm

This is a silencer for the M4 Combat Machine (airsoft) by G&G.
Unscrew the current cast iron barrel. And plug this silencer in its place - it runs from the picatinny rail all the way to the barrel tip.
Total length is 173mm (excluding a section then goes into the picatinny rail gap, for stability)
Inner hole is diameter 9mm (1mm more than most inner barrels)
Outer Diameter is 38mm (same as the ring inside the picatinny rail)
The outer section that plugs into the picatinny is 20mm outer diameter, and 7mm long
Silencer is thus 180mm total length
(THIS IS NOT A FUNCTIONING SILENCER AND IS PURELY COSMETIC FOR AIRSOFT USE)

description.text: For those of you who have accidentally put your tool into the blades of the extruder fan... (Pause for laughter)... I made this retrofit fan blade design.  I'm using it now and it works great.

• All you have to do is carefully remove the blade fins from your existing fan. I did this with an X-acto knife very carfully.

  • What you should be left with is a cylinder shape onto which this part should fit onto by pressure.

  • Carefully press fit the new blades onto the fan assembly.
    • Yes, while I was printing this I didn't have a fan going, but it's a short print and aftwards you will be back to 100% functionality. I printed in standard resolution on a Replicator 2 with Makerware.

comments.text: Thanks for posting this, you saved my bacon!
comments.author: Big-E

comments.text: If you have a tendency to put your tool where it shouldn't be it is best to use protection. :-)  There are a lot of good fan guards in thingiverse.  I use them now after a very similar event on my Prusa Mendel with a high power server cooling fan. Ouch!! :-)

author: elvisior

description.text:
This is my 1st concept to print project. I've printed lots of stuff from thingiverse so I figured I should give back a little.
This adapter fits the older Etrex (yellow, 12 channel) GPS. I needed this so I could connect the GPS to my kenwood D710 for use with APRS. I like this GPS cause they are inexpensive and I don't mind having it dedicated to APRS.

get 4 jewelers screws with flat heads. (mind you, anything less than an M4 is a jewelers screw to me).
Solder a lead to the screw, thread it back thru the adapter.
Because the print is so small, the 3rd and 4th hole are left open with the key-notch. But once inserted into the adapter, it all holds pretty tight. I did increase the size of the left and right tab in order to help it fit more snug.
If you can improve the design, please do ... and let me know cause I wouldn't mind having a better one

description.text: This is a bumper I made for the Gotway MCM 14" electric unicycle. I originally made it with the intention of having it hold together the frame now that most of the lower screwholes shafts had broken off, but ended up adding legs to it so that it can stand on its own.

Installation instructions
  1. Slot it into the front or back of the unicycle
  2. Secure with duct tape.
  3. If the unicycle tilts to one side and keeps falling down (the side with the battery is heavier), file down the leg of the other side.

comments.text: I printed this - I have mixed feeling - it printed at night - I got it taped and stick to fender but on first hole in the road it broke and fell off - it may be good to ride at home on carpet but not on the street
comments.author: MadPrint

comments.text: It's fine on the street. I've taken several crashes and several hundred km with the thing attached to the front of my wheel. Just beware of high steps. Coming down clips off the legs if you have it at the back, and trying to go up clips off the legs if you have it in front. Slopes are fine, and small 45° ramps seem to be fine.

title: Case for Papilio Duo FPGA and LCD Projects

description.text:
This is a simple case that will enclose the Papilio Duo FPGA board, 7" LCD screen, and analog joystick. I used it for a Mandelbrot fractal explorer project. I have made the SketchUp file available in case anyone wishes to tailor it for their own Papilio Duo project, e.g., a Papilio Arcade project, or even a project using another board such as a Raspberry Pi.

Here is a short YouTube video of my fractal project with this case. The text in the YouTube link contains more information about this FPGA project:
https://youtu.be/OqxMnT_Ruuk

The code for this project can be found at: https://github.com/elkayem/Mandelbrot-Explorer

A few details on the hardware:

  • The mounting hole pattern is designed for the Papilio Duo, and mounts with M2 nylon bolts. It can be easily modified in SketchUp to mount a different board (e.g., other Papilio boards, Arduino, Raspberry Pi, Beaglebone, etc).
  • The LCD mount fits a 7" LCD screen with display driver board. The one I used can be found by searching "7 inch 1024*600 TFT LCD Display Driver Board HDMI VGA 2AV for Raspberry Pi" on eBay. I've included a picture of the one I used. The case design includes a mount for the display driver on the back of the LCD screen, using M2 nylon bolts.
  • A mount is included for a PS2 style analog joystick. There are a lot of joystick modules out there with slightly different hole patterns. I've included an image of the one I used, which is available from all the usual sources for a few dollars. Search for "joystick module arduino" and you should be able to find this one. Or modify the SketchUp for your own module. (Note: the Papilio Duo includes an AVR chip, programmable using the Arduino IDE. The analog joystick can be read by this AVR chip.)
  • My project required two buttons and rotary encoder, all of which required a 6mm diameter hole. Your own project may require something different. The hole placement and size can easily be modified in SketchUp.
  • The top and bottom of this case attach together using M3 standoffs. I used two 30mm male/female brass standoffs connected together. I intentionally did not raise the walls of the case all the way so I could easily access the electronics inside while the case is closed. Again, the walls can easily be raised in SketchUp if you desire a sealed case.

Hopefully someone finds this all useful. I admit it's a pretty specific application, but the design can be modified to suit your own project's needs.

comments.text: good to see some Papilio gear :)

http://meettheslavs.com/dajbog-god-gives-lord-sun/

DAJBOG – THE GOD THAT GIVES – THE LORD OF THE SUN

Dajbog is considered to be the God of the Sun, originally presented as the son of Svarog. If we were to make parallels between Greek and Slavic Gods, Dajbog and Svarog would be equivalent to Helios and Zeus. Some mythologists claim that Dajbog would be better described if compared with Apollo.

Some ancient written sources imply that Dajbog is not just the God of the Sun, but also the bringer of the rain, highly worshiped and respected by the cult of Rain, Dodole. Dodole was a group of young and beautiful girls, usually virgins who performed rituals in the drought periods. They usually danced dressed in white or naked, wearing flower garlands on their head, singing and praying for the rain to come and put the drought to an end.

Dajbog was considered to be the God that gives, bringing rich crops, mowing and harvest, as well as bringing new life, helping families expand and mothers giving birth to many healthy children. Overall, in Russia, Poland and Bulgaria, Dajbog is primarily considered to be the personification of the Sun itself. Instead of worshiping solely things that could be found in nature, as they did by then, Slavs begin to give their Gods human names and other traits and characteristics, making each God more or less inclined to humans. Dajbog was one of the Gods that highly benefited the human race, giving life, through the warmth of the Sun. Dajbog is mainly considered to be the God of rain, Sun and fertility.

Variations of Dajbog between Slavs

For Western Slavs, Dajbog is considered to be the fire, rather than the sun itself. Even though they also considered Dajbog to be the son of Svarog, they thought he represented fire that could be found in nature after the lightning stroke, as well as fire that kept people warm in their homes. In Russia and Bulgaria, Dajbog was mainly the God of the Sun, while in some cultures Dajbog was also worshiped as a life giver, which is mainly equivalent to the Sun that gives life to every creature on Earth. Later, due to the mainstreaming of Christianity, Dajbog becomes a synonym for the Devil, having Christians transforming his name from Dajbog to Dabo, as a process of removing the paganism as the main competition.

Etymology of Dajbog’s Name

The name Dajbog was mainly used in Serbia to address the God of the Sun, having the name created out of two words: Daj– which is extracted from the verb Dati, which means Give, and the word Bog, which means God. Therefore, if the name Dajbog was literally translated, it would mean The God who Gives, or The Giving God. Except Dajbog, the God of Sun is also called Дажбог (Dažbog), where the word дажд (dažd) means rain. Variations in his name are present, but meaning and the cult he represented is somewhat similar for all Slavs, having Dajbog representing one of the most worshiped Slavic Gods.

This thing is a music controller in the sense that it forms a variable resistor that is adjustable by finger touch when printed with Proto-pasta conductive filament. Being spiral in nature, the thing bends when lateral pressure is applied which changes the electrical resistance between the terminals.

I like this thing as it is, yet really when you think of it, just about any shape can serve as a resistor if printed with conductive filament. Geometric shapes come to mind, as do ornamental and organic shapes. Imagine the "potential"!

I have chosen to accept the default license for this item which allows commercial use freely, so have at it if you need it for biz. i would appreciate if you do find a use for it in the biz world or in hobby world or whatever you do with it, please comment and/or post a make. This keeps me motivated to create more cool stuff! Thanks a bunch in advance...

Les

Usage

The terminals on opposite sides have holes designed to accept 3mm or similar hardware. This hardware should include washers suitable for mechanical and electrical contact. You use an insulating panel material, drill two holes to accept the hardware, then attach with hardware. Use spade lugs or twisted wire between two washers under the panel to accomplish electrical contact.

Electrically, connect one contact to Vcc (+5V) from an Arduino, the other contact to the analog 5 (A5) pin. Then connect a 4.7 kOhm resistor with one lead on the A5 pin of the Arduino and the other lead on Ground.

These two elements then form a voltage divider such that the equations in the Processing program unwrap and convert back from the measured voltage into a resistance value. In this way the resistance of the Finger Potentiometer is always known.

The program then converts the resistance value of the Finger Pot into a frequency setting for the sine wave oscillator. The sine wave then acts as the frequency modulated part of a Theremin, or in other words it acts like a VCO (Voltage Controlled Oscillator).

In addition to serving as a VCO, the Processing program loops back to any other application on the computer via localhost in the form of OSC (Open Sound Control) so that it can become a general purpose music controller (or robot controller or whatever else).

Also there is a bit of customization required in setting the Serial Port (USB Port) by selection from a list of Serial Ports Detected. This customization process is described in the source code comments, so be sure to read the comments on this one. Finally, to shut off the VCO you will have to disable it by modifying the source code.

comments.text: I have added a fourth image, the one with three coils in it.  This image shows the improvement of dual layering, where the bottom layer is printed in ordinary PLA and the top layer is printed in conductive PLA.  This improvement allows the use of metal front panels and also separates the conductive PLA from the build plate as I was having problems with it sticking to the glass build plate.  Yield is further improved by running the nozzle hot, at about 225 degrees.  I will upload version 6 of the SCAD file now.

title: Ox cnc gantry bracket for drag chain

description.text:
A bracket to mount the drag chain on the gantry on my ox cnc. The drag chain I bought, is 9,5x10mm (if you consider to buy a drag chain for you ox, then buy a 10x20 mm). The whole in the drag chain for mounting it is 3mm - I drilled that up to 5 mm.

The bracket is made so it will not block the motor, if you need to move to motor all the way to the top position, for tensing the belt.

Ps. I think the clinical term, if you are missing one nut is is "toroid"... I guess my cnc might still be able to reproduce ;)

UPDATE 20160630: Version 2 uploaded. I moved the mount-plate-thingy 4 mm down to align the cables better with the plat on the ox.

UPDATE 20170216: Uploaded a version for 15x40 drag chain.

description.text:
Here's a way we can chat about our creations, Hold virtual events, engage in some online gaming, and other stuff.
Right now, it's just a Windows client, and there's not much there to explore. But the chat works, and you can explore the virtual world a bit... If interest grows, I'll create a cross-platform version, a way to share/collect things, and add more places to explore...(and whatever else you guys want...) :) Hope you enjoy this and find it useful - I just started this yesterday, so it may take a little time till I add more fun stuff... (but I WILL!) I am hoping that posting this isn't breaking any rules, or causes any grief that's the last thing I want to do. Be well.
-TDA

It's downright simple to enter MAKERBOTOPIA:
  • Download the client (5 mb)
    http://augworld.com/makerbotopia/makerbotopia.exe
    ("save", don't "open")
  • Launch the client.
  • Enter your name
  • Hit the enter key or click "connect"
    • That should be it. PLEASE be nice in there. :) Any questions regarding this, ping me at [email protected] -TDA

author: Knapek12

title: Makergear X-Carriage with built-in fan mount and duct for cooling nozzle.

description.text:
Are you having cooling troubles with your hotend?  Filament jambs?  Too much fiddling with cleaning up stuck filament and too many dis-assemblies?  This is one good solution.  This replacement x-carriage should help anyone out who prints with pla or abs.  Many fiament jambs happen when the hotend becomes heat saturated higher up.  Then filament softens then as the filament is driven downward it mushrooms out and jambs higher up in the nozzle.
I didn't find one that I liked so I put this together to direct a nice cool flow of air to the upper portion of the hot-end.  It takes a common 40 mm cpu/gpu fan and is a really clean method to attach a fan.  
I hope it is useful for everyone needing better cooliing for the hotend.
I've uploaded the final V4 STL called "xcarriagev4done_fixed.stl".  It has been passed through Netfabb and is only 2.6 megs compared to 12.3 megs for V3.  It prints nicely without requiring any support.  The fan mount clears the diagonals nicely and the bushings fit well, too.
I should have a V5 with linear slides and a raised hotend but can't promise when it will arrive.
Enjoy!

Print it out and install it! The X-Carriage-V4 loads onto your build bed and prints on edge.

edit < I used a heat gun to warm up the four corners where the bronze bushes press in. With a little heat they slid in smoothly. > /edit <

I'm using my first version today and the little fan and duct does an awesome job. The MakerGear hotend can maintain 180 for PLA, but struggles for go any higher than maybe 185 C. I hope the plugged nozzles are a thing of the past with this upgrade. Good luck everyone and please let me know how it works out. I have uploaded V4. I just received my new hotends from hotends.com they look awesome btw :). The cooling fins were a few mms higher than I had expected so I re-contoured the air ramp and outlet to allow a better air flow a little higher up on the nozzle. The new fan bracket is thinner. It's just as strong but uses less plastic. Use the V4 x-carriage for both the Makergear hotend and for the hotend.com finned power resistor hotend. Talk about the "evolution of a design"! I wonder how many more changes I'll have to the idea! :) I've just uploaded new photos showing the new X-Carriage with the Birdnose extruder. They go very well together! I'm also working on a new x-carriage that raises the hotend 3 cm so the total Z travel on the MakerGear Prusa should be at or over 11 cm and it will use linear slides for near zero friction.

comments.text: What was this designed in?  we might like to make a few tweaks if you'd be okay with that?  Post up the design files for whichever platform you're using and we'll do the rest.  We completely understand if you'd prefer not to as well.

Pro/E student version does save to slt, step, and iges so it is still awesomely useful for 3D printing.

author: hermani

description.text:
im a new designer and i couldnt figure out how to add holes to the bottom sides under where the little platform inside is by using a solder iron.
No supports needed!
Supplies:
LOTS of electric/duct tape (preferably duct tape)

Water Proof 12volt motor

12volt Duracell battery

Some wire with insulation

Super glue

Plastic Sandwich ZipLock bag

Boat Propeller

Instructions for water proof 12volt motor:
Put the motor in the sandwich back with the rod sticking out of one of the ends of the ZipLock part. Make 2 holes near the top of the bag for feeding the wire through. Grab your duct tape (or electric tape) and then cover the whole bag in about 3-4 layers of tape while also making sure you have covered as much of the ZipLock part of the bag where the rod of the motor sticks out as much as possible while also making sure that the rod can turn.
As well as making sure the rod is water proof, make sure you have covered the two wire feed holes in plenty of tape as well

You can download the Boat propeller needed for this project
right here --> http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:424313

I dropped the tank on my Bissell ProHeat 2X Pet carpet shampooer, and the handle broke. My immediate response to my wife was, "I wonder if I can print a replacement for it." Turns out, I can!

Worked out a suggestion by cjohnson44546 to separate the tiles. Each tile is now separately printable and has a groove in the bottom to fit in the grid.
The grid is a 3x3 square and can be extended with connector pieces.

In addition to this basic grid, I want to add taller ones, so boards with ramps are also possible. I have not yet done this.

Note: setting up the game board might take some time now :-)

Supports:

No

Instructions

Select the tiles you want in the grid. Print them (no support needed).
I left out the pits, which you get, obviously, when not filling a tile in the grid.
Then print 1 or more grids. No support needed.
Print connectors to connect the grids. Connectors work as a separate row for tiles.
The corner connectors sit in the middle of 4 grids.
The edge connectors are used on the edges between two grids.
The normal connectors are used between two grids.

author: Haywiire

title: RoboCat 270mm DIY Quadcopter Drone - Amazing!
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hi Thingiverse friends, I'd like to share my experience in the construction of my first racing drone.
I've never assembled one before, (so everything is a surprise for me) to get started in the world of drones and after make some search, in my opinion this kit is a perfect base for it.

In this thread i will adding the 3D printable improvements that go specifically designed for this model all ready Done:
Power PCB Support

Future improvements: Led light for Tail / Nose, Camera Supports ,GPS Supports, Battery holder


This RoboCat 270 kit has been courtesy of Gearbest guys, one serious and very big website were you can both for setting up your DIY drone or to get yours already assembled from factory and soo on. Thank you all you guys!! you are Awesome!!


Back to the drone , this thread includes actually all you need for assemble your Drone.
here you can see the components i use in this project and all the tech spec:

Carbon fiber Quadcopter Frame
Marspower 2204 Motors x4
Propeller 5030 x4
CC3D flight controller
power distribution board
Lipo LiFe Low Voltage Buzzer Alarm
12A motor ESC
battery 2200mAh 11.1V 30C Lipo
Transmitter
Charger compatible
kit with some parts

This RoboCat feels very balanced from beginning, against other equivalent others, this has very good reputation for its fine stability of flight and response. Easy to drive and assemble in a simple beautiful line. For all that reasons it has been selected to start this project.

Also is fully upgradeable one of the things because i love it.
This means little by little you will be able to add more things to your drone, to leave it as you like... GPS, FPV, 3D Print improvements, etc..

Carbon fiber chassis feels rugged, lightweight. It has a thickness of 1.5mm thick fuselage and 3mm thick arms for better support the power from motors . In the videos you can see a fast assemble and all parts received in a single pass.

Hardware is very easy to identify it comes with not instructions, but however leave an image that came to me very well for the Assembly of the Robo.

Patience at the time to assembly It is also recommended, above all if it is the first time that you mount something, you do it somewhere quiet, with enough space to see all parts and work in a comfortable area.

I had never build one before and it took about 30 hours (counting tests and other surprises along the way).

I don't think that required any technical special knowledge to come out all right, perhaps more complicated for some of the mounted, may be it welds with Tin (but is very easy with a little of practice)

Here you can see clearly as they have to go the engine welded to the ESC, so two rotate in clockwise direction and the other two to the contrary.



These engines can get to spin very fast, certainly for this drone are more than enough. A touch of throttle and shoots out the drone.
The advantage of these motors and brushless is that friction is minimal. Which translates into better performance and less maintenance.

I've see that many of the people who assemble this kit say that power PCB, does not work for this model.

This is not entirely correct, I've been able to fit it perfectly, including the two frames carbon fiber which includes the chassis.
The trick is cut to size. This Power PBC is also made as an octocopter, (but we are not going to use those connections) Then the best way to go is cut.



To secure the power PCB to the chassis, I designed a piece that fits perfectly with this board model and fixed with screws to the chassis of the RoboCat.


On the next floor of the drone, we have the battery compartment, I've chosen one of 30C / 3S, giving power for 10 or 12 minutes of flight.

In future 3D improvements shure i make some support for quick battery replacement.

The only problem that I found when installing the control flight CC3D, is that I was able to integrate the anti-vibration support that comes in the Kit.

A layer above, we have the CC3D, has captivated me, super simple to set up, has been to connect it by usb to the ground station, and in less than 10 minutes to have everything set up and ready to fly.



Think it is advisable to protect from vibration everything we can this Board, but I have been unable. At the end what I did was stick it to the middle frame, as shown in the video.



The software of this flight controller is based on "librepilot" open source so it is perfect to configure it as you need.
Depending on your level of rider, you can start softer and not broke your drone while learning to fly.
once you already take more esperience is going to be easy to modify the parameters of your Robocat and load more aggressive flight configs on your CC3D board.
For more information about Librepilot see this link



Connected to the CC3D I have the receiver and Transmitter Sky Fly FS T6, with a simple wiring per channel and protected by the external housing feline line from this model.

On the right side, I had to drill a little the side plastic protection, since it could not connect the ESC drivers.

In my conclusion, this drone i believe that it can make dreams reality of anyone interested in started in the world of the drains with a serious model and quality.

Not be mistaken when I say is also a drone for starters, this dorne has a RACING spirit in all parts of his body and configured in an aggressive flight mode, it can be very very fast..

I have learned to fly dornes with it , i steel no too much good, but 100% recommend for start, is easy to Fly and config. I can help with the basic configuration from the Transmitter and the CC3D flightboard. Message me if you have trubles. here a new video of the first flight video here


-------------------------------------------------


If this thing was helpful or you like the designs, please click the "like" button. in that way I will continue sharing more things.
If you print one I would love to see it in the section "i made one" of course, all views and advice are welcomed, you can always improve design..

print_settings.Notes:: I printed my test print using a sample of Semiflex I had laying around.  Printed wtih 3 top and bottom layers it feels a bit squishy.  For durability I'd say probably go with 4-5 bottom layers since it's going to be getting poked by the clutch interlock switch.  I'd imagine you could just use ABS as well if you prefer and it would work out fine for what it is.

description.text:
Replacement for "Rubber Stopper", Mazda part number B001-43-029 (part 13 in the attached diagram). If you own an NA or NB Miata for long enough you'll eventually find yourself with a clutch pedal that makes a "clicky" sound when pressed or released. This happens with the little rubber stopper on the clutch pedal disintegrates and the metal clutch pedal arm clicks against the plastic plunger on the clutch interlock switch. The replacement part is less than $2, but you have to either make a trip to the dealer parts counter and/or order it and wait. Print this out, stick it in the hole on the pedal and be done with it.

Original pictured left, test print (in clear Semiflex) on right. Print looks from the pics to be a bit smaller in diameter and thicker but this is an illusion caused by some casting flash on the original and the fact that the original has a bit more round-over around the parameter of the large face.

Printer:

Flashforge Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.200mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I printed my test print using a sample of Semiflex I had laying around. Printed wtih 3 top and bottom layers it feels a bit squishy. For durability I'd say probably go with 4-5 bottom layers since it's going to be getting poked by the clutch interlock switch. I'd imagine you could just use ABS as well if you prefer and it would work out fine for what it is.
Measured the original piece with digital calipers and recreated in Sketchup. Reuploaded 7/4 as I had a brain fart and forgot to select the model when exporting STL for my initial upload.

title: Bad Mother Fucker Leather Stamp
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Bad Mother Fucker leather stamp.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NUuwd8Z0l_4
You will need a 0.25mm nozzle to print it 100%, scale accordingly.

To use it, get vegetal tanned leather, spray a bit of water on it to dampen the surface, wait a a minute, position the stamp on the leather and press on a flat surface.
I usually use a small wooden board to lay on top of the stamp and stand on it shifting my weight in all direction to get a good inprint.

Edit : I have added an inverted version, it can be printed with a standart 0.4mm nozzle.

Just print the holder and then buy a Batavus bike and a Xiaomi mi4 smartphone to go with it :) No, just kidding. I added a step file so it is easier to change for a different sized phone. Unfortunately this holder probably will only fit certain batavus bikes. My odometer broke ages ago so I thought it was time for an upgrade with slightly more functionality. I included a picture that shows the handlebar lever before i put the bracket on. First open the lever and then you can remove the black plate just by pressing it from the back. It will pop off nicely. Slide the phone holder in the lever and close the lever. Once the lever is closed you the phone holder will be firmly stay in place. My Xiaomi mi4 fits in snuggly with its siliconcover on.

description.text:
Model of an ambiguous solid.

Look at it from one direction it appears to be a cube, and from the opposite it appears to be a cylinder. Hold it up to a mirror and you see both at the same time.

The 4x model is a group of four of the shapes merged together to produce the illusion of either 4 connected cubes or four overlapping cylinders.

The models ending in correct have been reworked to use a more mathematically correct construction method. They will have a 30 degree up from horizontal viewing angle.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

This was very difficult for me to print as removing the supports without damaging the print was a problem.
Take care when removing the support material as it is easy to split the model.

After seeing this video (not my video), I had to try and model this shape.

I created a cube in Blender, subdivided the sides so I would be able to smoothly deform it. I worked from the final viewing angle and distorted the cube until it looked like a cylinder. I switched to the opposite viewing angle and made sure the object looked like a cube.

Tim,

Now I'm trying to get the photos off my phone to add an "I made one" to your listing. Thanks for the file and the fix! Hope to see more of these!
comments.author: MrBill72012

comments.text:
Tim,
I certainly appreciate your efforts, but apparently Cura doesn't like the file. Looks like there's a gap at the center where the four pieces all should join, and another gap where those four pieces meet the outside wall. I thought it was because I had scaled them down to 50%, and saw the gaps in an actual print-in-progress, but I deleted them and reloaded a fresh copy, went in and looked at the layer view and saw the same gaps. I'm fairly new at this, but have gone through about 10 rolls of filament and made some good looking prints. Can't think of anything I could adjust to correct this, any ideas?
comments.author: MrBill72012

comments.text: The models were definitely non-manifold. I have corrected the issues and replaced the files. If you download them now, you should have fewer issues.
comments.author: MrBill72012

comments.text:
If you go into Expert->Open expert settings... CTRL-E
You can choose Combine everything (Type-A) under Fix Horrible.
That should close the gaps.
I don't know how small this can be scaled and still print as the walls are only 2.5mm thick.
I can do a proper merge in Blender before I export and see if that creates a better file.
If it does, I will add it.
comments.author: MrBill72012

comments.text:
Looks like the best version of these so far. I think you might be the first to post a multiple cube solution.

comments.text: It's actually part of the illusion. So the bottom of the cylinders appear round and the bottom of the squares appear as square. It would have been a lot easier to print with a flat bottom.

10%

Notes:

printed in PLA on any setting.
connector and switch were "resqued" from an old computer psu destined for the scrapyard

After printing a design found here, i discovered the measurements of that design were all wrong for my power supply (stupid me, should have checked better).
I then desided to completely remake that design from scratch, but now suitable for my power supply and here is the result of my first design.
A mains connector and on/off switch rescued from an old computer power supply were used to fill the holes. Mount the mainsconnector onto the piece with M3 bolts and a nut. The switch just slots in the hole.
The outgoing 12volts wires are threaded through te halfround hole on the rightside wich is partly covering a hole in the 8mm acrilyc frame and .... voila ..... no more (un)plugging a wire, but simply flip a switch to turn on/off my 3d printer.

This is a custom distance piece for the lower fan on the Zortrax M200.

title: adjustable camera mount for ZMR 250 and 38mm SONY CCD camera

description.text: HobbyKing's SONY CCD 1/3inch Camera doesn't fit inside the ZMR 250 frame, so I designed this build to overcome this problem. I sawed the top plate of the frame, and replaced the front standoffs with my design. It came out very nicely, with no alignment issues. The stand is adjustable between 0° and 20°, and it locks with friction. It's very rigid, and doesn't come loose during flight.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

75%

Notes:

The print mostly contains base planes, and thin walls.
Print time: ~1h.

Additional parts:

For this build, you will need:
-1 M3x45mm screw
-1 M3 hex locknut
-4 pcs M2x10mm self tapping screws
-2 pcs M2.5 hex locknut (or regular)
-2 pcs M2.5 screws

Preparations

You will need to cut the top plate of the frame to be able to fit the camera. Sorry this is not a Möbius friendly build. The cut line is marked with red on the attached Image. Remove the aluminium standoffs, and the screws (save them for later, they can come in handy).

Assembly instructions
  • Insert the camera in the front Camera piece, then put on the back piece facing the flat side out (it should snap on).
  • Secure it with the self tapping screws.
  • Drop the smaller nuts into the hexagonal openings, and bolt it to the bottom plate of the frame.
  • Push the bigger nut into the hex cut on the side, and align the holes of the base part with the camera front part's holes. Push the long screw trough the holes, and mate it with the nut.
Adjusting the camera angle

To adjust the angle of the camera, loose the long screw on the bottom, set the desired angle, then tighten it up again.
Be Careful! If you set it too tight, you may break the parts!

I've designed these parts to be 3d-printer friendly, with the least amount of external parts.
I added extra material at the crucial points, and used fillets where it was necessary.

title: Y axis Pulley mount Prusa i3- Aluminum frames (Max MIcron and others)

description.text:
Added3mm lifted, toothed idler mount- smaller footprint also

••note, there is a 3mm lifted version that raises the bearing 3mm's to get a better (though probably still not perfect) belt line••

broken 2 stock y mounts for the Max Micron, 1st was just cheap printing too thin, the 2nd was sorta my own fault for over tightening the pulley holding nut and it squeezed and cracked the support.. but really, the thing should be stronger!! SO... I made one stronger!! kinda over kill, but not going to break any time soon!! everything possible is rounded off instead of sharp angles so less stress cracking areas.

pulley bolt/nut is design for the stock M3 size. nut is recessed and held in place so no tool needed on that side. it's a tad tight, you'll likely need to mount the nut on the screw just at the end, push nut into place from the back, then remove screw and mount everything up. Frame mount screws are again the stock sized M5's with the washer.
